Award.AwardTitle: Kids as Urban Scientists: Mapping the Biodiversity of the Philadelphia Promise Zone

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by providing immersive field experiences for inner-city students from groups underrepresented in STEM fields. Upper elementary students will use digital data collection tools to map biodiversity in local neighborhoods, and the project will interweave the biodiversity activities with career awareness and mentoring opportunities. Digital badging will be used to certify learning accomplishments and provide recognition for students and teachers engaged in the project. The project consists of three components: a) Development of a curriculum module focusing on biodiversity for use in school or in out-of-school learning environments; b) Integration of career awareness and mentoring activities by college science faculty or students who will work with students during the biodiversity mapping activities; and c) Professional development opportunities for schoolteachers and out-of-school educators.

The project will engage 400 inner-city students in grades 4-6 along with 80 teachers and out-of-school-time (OST) educators from the Philadelphia Promise Zone, one of the highest poverty areas in the country. The curriculum modules for each grade will be designed for use in either a school classroom or an OST setting, and the disciplinary content will be aligned with relevant disciplinary core ideas and science practices of the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). The curriculum modules at each grade level will include classroom learning activities, a field component for data collection, and a final sessions where teams of students present their findings through development of a poster, a video, or some other visual representation. A mixed-methods research approach will be used to seek findings related to three research questions: a) What coherent set of experiences effectively support fourth, fifth and sixth grade students? knowledge development (e.g., biodiversity content knowledge blended with science practices), motivation and career awareness about STEM-related work and jobs of today and the future? b) What professional development models and recognition systems can effectively engage teachers and OST providers in demonstrating Next Generation Science knowledge, pedagogy, and career awareness for fourth through sixth grade students? and c) How effective is the activity of Promise Zone fourth-sixth grade students as information providers and Urban Scientists interacting with scientist mentors towards increasing career awareness and understanding characteristics of STEM work?

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the last few years, science policy and national standards documents have outlined a vision for science education that emphasizes phenomena-centric curricular activities and learning through science investigation and engineering design (e.g., NRC, 2014, NRC, 2019). While the vision is clear, the documents are lean in details of how to develop coordinated systems of a curricular unit, assessment instruments, and professional development resources that collectively guide and support students and teachers to realize these goals.

 

Intellectual Merit

Kids as Urban Scientists developed a comprehensive Open-Source Science instructional system for late elementary students and teachers within a national Promise Zone; an area with patterns of persistent poverty.  We use the term Open-Source Science to refer phenomenon-centric learning where student work is organized around science investigation and the creation of designed solutions and student learning has a purpose and audience beyond classroom walls. The work outlines the steps in the design and evaluation of a coordinated system five-weeks of phenomenon-centric activities, summative and formative assessments, and professional development resources that anchor student learning through the study of local phenomena and the design of solutions to increase urban biodiversity. Student solution creation is mentored by professional scientists and the solutions are modeled after solutions found to be helpful by professionals, including increasing flowering plants to attract pollinators. Cycles of research studies focusing on student learning and career awareness were conducted. Two cycles of learning were evaluated using paired t-tests. Research results demonstrated significant learning outcomes by urban third-sixth grade students on Next Generation Science performance expectations in association with participation in the five-week curricular unit. In addition, a summer extension program supported students in the implementation of their local solutions and a deeper understanding of the work of scientists and themselves as doing science.

 

Broader Impacts

The suite of materials were designed with and for students and teachers in culturally, racially and linguistically diverse, under-resourced schools within a nationally-designated Promise Zone. Neighborhoods are economically challenged, and students demonstrate patterns of underperformance on state standardized tests. These target populations were selected for several reasons including the dearth of immersive, Next Generation Science learning experiences provided to these students in the past, and the productive, ongoing relationships between school personnel and the project staff that have contributed towards learning improvements in other content areas (mathematics). This project was designed to go beyond students? and teachers? learning. In addition, the resources, changes in classroom practice, and research studies championed students? ability to see that their own science learning has value to others through the generation of biodiversity information for local stakeholders? use in environmental improvements and provided individual case study analyses to address questions of what works when and for whom.
